fields.headline: The ballad of James Bay
fields.bodyText: In early February, under a railway bridge in Camden, beside the pub made famous by Amy Winehouse’s patronage, a huge poster of the English musician James Bay appeared. The billboard announced the release of the 24-year-old singer-songwriter’s debut album, Chaos and the Calm, on 23 March. But the timing and the placement of the ad must also have been strategic: it was pasted up a couple of days before his gig down the road at Koko, the biggest show of his life so far. Many fans would have seen it as they travelled to the venue; perhaps even Bay himself as he came in from his flat in north London. When I meet Bay on the morning after the gig – a happening notable for a) the crowd knowing word-for-word songs from an album that hasn’t even come out yet and b) a lot of people wearing fedoras, Bay’s trademark, like an Indiana Jones convention – I ask if he had driven past the poster on the way to Koko. “I still haven’t seen it, but someone sent me a photo and I’m buzzing,” he replies. “Wow! Oh, mad! Crazy! It’s a big moment for me, man. We’ve all grown up seeing things like that and it will be so cool to go up to it in person.” Bay pauses, thinks. “I want to see someone draw a cock on my face,” he decides. “I want to see that. Great, because it means that it’s real. You’re never too big to have a pair of balls drawn on your chin. Nobody in the world. To have the eyes scratched out of a picture. Nobody.” If Bay is incredulous, it is easy to understand why. Six months ago, he was unknown; scarcely more than a year ago, he was still working in pubs in his hometown of Hitchin, Hertfordshire. A break of sorts came when Lana Del Rey was a no-show for Fearne Cotton’s Live Lounge on Radio 1 last September; Bay stepped in, played his 2014 single “Let It Go” and began trending on Twitter. He was runner-up in the BBC’s Sound of 2015 and then went one better, winning the 2015 Brits Critics’ Choice award. Few prizes are such a dependable guarantee of future megastardom: Adele, Florence & the Machine, Ellie Goulding, Jessie J, Emeli Sandé, Tom Odell and Sam Smith are all past winners. Bay seems to have admirers in high places, from the fashion designer Christopher Bailey, who asked him to play live at the Burberry Prorsum show in last autumn’s London Fashion Week, to Taylor Swift, who has seen him perform twice. After the first gig in Nashville, Swift launched into a detailed dissection of “Let It Go”, a tiny bit awkward since Bay didn’t know any of her songs to return the compliment. (He’s more of a Feist man.) “She’s not one of my favourites, but God, that’s OK,” he says. “I think it’s all right that I don’t know her back catalogue.” On the second occasion, an industry showcase in Los Angeles before last month’s Grammy Awards, Swift suggested that Bay open for her during her European tour this summer. “I’m hugely grateful for the invite,” says Bay. “I don’t think she’d be coming at me if she didn’t like the music. And those are going to be enormous venues, so it gives me a taste of that scale. Why not be young and naive and hope that I’ll get to that level at some stage?” Much of Bay’s life right now is glamorous – but not today. We are sitting in a pub in High Barnet, perusing a never-ending menu while builders down a lunchtime pint. “I’ve got to go beef burger and chips, cheese, no bacon,” declares Bay, with an endearing enthusiasm he might not have had if he’d seen, as I had, the chef standing catatonic alone in the kitchen. “Or should it be fish and chips? Oh my God, scampi!” And to drink? “Apple juice or orange juice. Apple juice first then orange juice.” Looking out of the window, while “Golden Brown” by the Stranglers warbles out of tinny speakers, Bay knows this kind of establishment and its environs well. “Mid-level,” he says. “All right. Livable. Not the most exciting thing in the world, but great. Easy to grow up in, which is what Hitchin was. Comfortable.” Chaos and the Calm – as the title hints – deals with the dramatic life changes that Bay has been dealing with in recent times. But even though he is now in the rarefied position of being sent by his label to write in LA, and the album was recorded in Nashville’s storied Blackbird Studio, Bay isn’t keen to ditch his upbringing entirely. The guitarist in his band, Tom, has been his best friend since primary school; he’s been with his girlfriend since they were teenagers in Hitchin. His biggest hit to date, “Hold Back the River”, laments gradually losing touch with loved ones. “You hear all these stories about pop stars who say, ‘I grew up in this small town and I had to break out and find the big city.’ I wasn’t like that as a little kid. I’m very close in age to my older brother and we had a field at the end of the road where we could run around, climb trees, play football. I couldn’t stand London.” In fact, when Bay was sent to Los Angeles to finish working on the album, he found he couldn’t write a line. Back home, the final tracks came easily. “I’ll always get dragged back to places like this,” says Bay, as our lunch arrives, suspiciously quickly. “It’s part of that age-old thing: never forget your roots. Well, I don’t want to.” He picks up a piece of scampi and pops it in his mouth. A month before, in mid-January, I’d met Bay at ITV’s South Bank studios as he prepared to record a song for a show called The Brits Are Coming!, broadcast later the same night. His award, voted for by music journalists and “industry experts”, was announced ahead of time and he was a couple of hours from playing in front of a television audience of millions. Arriving at the studios, he was confronted for the first time by a wall of paparazzi. Someone from the label called ahead and instructed him to get out of the left-hand side of the car. Bay smiled, “It’s all very new still. For a second every time, it’s a bit like, ‘This is fun!’” He appeared unfazed, but bristled when I said as much. “Please don’t make it seem like that,” he said. “I’m not Mr Fucking Big Balls. I’m really not. I’m not all confidence.” The point he was making was that this wasn’t some overnight success. After school, Bay went to the Brighton Institute of Modern Music (Bimm) partly because his girlfriend was already studying in the city but mostly because he looked on the website and liked a photograph of a wall covered in guitars. He’d started playing his uncle’s classic Spanish guitar with nylon strings when he was 11 and had been in bands through his teens, often in some configuration with his brother and Tom. At Bimm, Bay was in the same intake as the singer-songwriter Tom Odell. His course mostly taught him how cutthroat the music industry would be: “It’s dog eat dog. If you want it, you’ve got to want it more than the next guy, even if he’s your best friend.” Bay developed his sound at local open mics. Growing up, he was obsessed with Bruce Springsteen and Michael Jackson, and even now his tunes oscillate between growly anthems and delicate ballads that soar up into the falsetto register. Perhaps Bay’s greatest discovery in Brighton, however, was Mad Hatters, a headwear emporium in North Laine. He’d been listening to the American bluesman Eric Bibb, who is rarely seen without a panama, and Bay thinks there might be some entrenched memories of Bob Dylan and Robbie Robertson from the Band. Aged 20, he put on a dark fedora, decided he liked how it looked, and it has pretty much stayed there since. He’s on to his second one now, bought in Nashville, and is seriously considering investing in a hat box with all the transatlantic travelling he’s doing these days. The hat remains staunchly in place during our two meetings, but Bay plans to take it off one day. “I might shave my head,” he says. “I hope to have a long career and I don’t want to be defined by things that aren’t the music.” For now, though, it feels like a uniform: he puts it on and he’s ready for work. “It’s my suit. There should be an element of mystique between the fans and the artist. That bit between the stage and the audience. I think that’s necessary. I used to dress up like Michael Jackson. I didn’t have the glove, but I had a red jacket like in Thriller.” Bay has to GO. A car is picking him up at the pub, off to Dublin via Heathrow. After that: Amsterdam, home, New York for a sold-out show at the Bowery Ballroom, home, the South by Southwest festival in Texas, then home again for the album release and two weeks of UK dates. Bay is an easy target for some critics: too handsome, too palatable, too much like the posse of soulful British and Irish male balladeers such as George Ezra and Hozier, who’ve already made it. His response is to work relentlessly, as though he can silence the doubters one live show at a time. “Is it that they go, ‘He’s got a look and that’s why he’s where he’s at?’” Bay clicks his tongue, shakes his head. “That’s a shame. I understand that, because it’s the world we live in, but I’m more than pleased to show them I can play. Just sit down and have a listen and I’ll show you.” Chaos and the Calm is out on 23 March Follow the Observer Magazine on Twitter @ObsMagazine
